Award.AwardTitle: REU: AERO-U: Aerospace Engineering Research Opportunities for Undergraduates

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This three year REU Site award will engage 10 undergraduate students in research focuses in computational and experimental multi-scale physics in the Department of Aerospace Engineering at Texas A&M University. The objectives of this REU are to: (1) Involve a total of ten students, for ten-weeks in each of three summers, in three key research areas of multi-scale physics (solid mechanics, fluid and plasma dynamics, system dynamics and control); (2) Encourage participation of students from underrepresented minorities, which includes females; (3) Provide information on graduate school and encourage students to apply; (4) Provide opportunities for REU students to present and publish with faculty and collaborate beyond the summers if possible; and (5) Provide networking and community-building opportunities among REU, TAMU students, and faculty.

The project will enable access to limited research opportunities in multi-scale physics. Specific research areas include plasma flow physics and electromagnetic space propulsion systems, novel turbulence physics models, and hypersonic flow physics. Many of these areas are critical to national goals, USA leadership in space exploration, future aerospace transportation needs, and homeland security, in addition to connecting to current research and challenges faced by engineering on a global level.

The program also seeks to enhance and diversify the pool of talented students considering research careers in multi-scale physics by enabling access for women and underrepresented groups to aerospace engineering research. Participating students will be involved in research that can contribute to increased understanding of meso-scale and multi-scale physics and new approaches to modeling such phenomena. Faculty and student mentors will work closely with the College of Engineering's Institute of Engineering Education and Innovation on ensuring the experience includes aspects of multi-disciplinary design, experiential learning, systems thinking/engineering, and professional development for the students. In addition, the students will be a part of a larger group of undergraduate researchers through our collaboration with the College of Engineering's Undergraduate Summer Research Grant program, which works with in excess of 60 students each summer. Students who complete the program will be tracked through professional and social networking sites (Linked-In, Facebook, etc.). After participating, REU students will receive information they can use in recruiting for the REU or for outreach visits that they can initiate on their own and continue keeping this access to the careers open. Participating students will be required to display their posters and recruit future REU students at their home institutions, i.e., practice each one, reach one and teach one.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This lists the project outcomes for AERO-U; Aerospace Engineering Research Opportunities for Undergraduates REU Site (EEC 1157070, $386,113, 5/25/2012-12/31/2015;

PI: Lagoudas, co PIs Bowersox, EEC055295, $245,911, 3.1.2006-2/28/2009 and EEC 0735109, $10,000 extension for two additional students in Cohort in 2007; PI J. Richard, co-PIs Girimaji and Bowersox. Main results and lessons leared follow. First we list where the specific objectives of AERO-U REU have been met, then some sample research and lessons learned.

Objective 1: Target 10 students per year, 2 more than original REU. We total 39 from FY 2012 to 2016. The overall GPA of applicants has increased from the original REU to around 3.7. The PI could not always visit local institutions, with some changes beyond his control, but we have formalized recruiting ties with the Texas A&M Engineering Experiment Station (TEES) institutions. The overall number of applicants has increased with the online application system but the diversity of the applicant pool still requires personal visits.

In the three years of AERO-U (plus one-year no-cost extension( 42 students participated. The no-cost extension allowed for two students in 2016. The recent renewal funds came in May but that was too late for program start on May 31.

Objective 2: Encourage participation by underrepresented students. Over 66.67% of the program participants were from outside TAMU, about 50% of those were from under-represented groups and about 20% were women. We had about 346 applicants during the grant period, as the popularity and ranking of the school increased. However, the diversity of the applicant pool was limited with less than 16% women and about 11% minorities. However, we did get a higher percentage of women (20%) and minorities (40%) in participants vs. our applicant pool. About half of the participants were from underrepresented groups, thus matching the target of 50%. We had 18 different institutions of 21 represented over 90% non-TAMU students and 90% of those were from outside Texas.

Objective 3: About 60% of students are attending or plan to attend grad school. Most of the recent REU participants who plan to attend grad school are at least planning to get a Masters degree. Many of those are planning on a PhD; just under 30 % of AERO-U participants chose TAMU for graduate school (includes from groups typically under-represented in Aerospace Engineering).

Objective 4: Community-building among REU students. We did this through tours of on and off-campus facilities (the TAMU Immersive Visualization Center) http://ivc.tamu.edu/. where REU students worked; Ad Astra Rocket Co., near NASA Johnson in Houston, where REU students saw the Variable Specific Impulse Magneto-Plasma Rocket (VSIMR) being developed); lunch with faculty; social activities (picnics, pizza and pool parties,  etc,, not using NSF funds).

Objective 5: About a dozen REU students present and publish with faculty, Student-authored publications and conference presentations resulting from this REU [Collard et al. (2016); Richard et al. (2015)].Two REU students attended International conferences and presented.

BROADER IMPACTS

AERO-U successfully immersed students in leading-edge research to help them become world class-researchers enhancing US technological competitiveness. A student computationally simulated the interaction between magnetic, kinetic, and internal energies in homogeneously sheared magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) flows subject o perturbations in various directions. This is important for hypersonic flight. Integral to the NSF REU grant, students began implementing the Fourier-Galerkin spectral Method applied to the Boltzmann collision integral; Pareschi and Russio's [Pareschi and Russo, 2000] results were duplicated. In addition, we have a spectral Maxwell solver and a code version parallelized using the Standard Template Adaptive parallel library (STAPL) [An et al., 2001]. REU students contributed to finishing the construction of the National Aerothermochemistry Lab housing laser optics, a shock tunnel and the supersonic wind tunnels, a NASA-T-38 jet trainer Pitot-static probe corrosion patterns were simulated and tested.

In our surveys, over 70% of past AERO-U participants said that the REU increased their "interest and knowledge" of grad school. Knowledge of grad school was shared via seminars on applying to grad school, financing it, grad student panels, luncheons and through tours of on-and off-campus facilities; brown bag lunches; social activities (picnics, pizza and pool parts, etc). The university established an early-admission program whereby top REU participants get admitted early to grad school. Typical student post-REU comments include: "This has helped me decide that I want to go to graduate school," and "I really enjoyed working with the professor I was paired with. It definitely pushed me over the edge & into applying for graduate school."
